headline.main: Study of Chimps Strongly Backs Salt's Link to High Blood Pressure

docs.lead_paragraph: VITAL to life and sought worldwide for its taste, common salt has played a large role in history because of its scarcity in many times and places. Salt has figured in wars, the North African slave trade and an onerous tax in prerevolutionary France. But today salt is cheap and plentiful. Many experts say, in fact, that its wide use is largely responsible for an epidemic of high blood pressure and many resulting deaths from heart disease in the United States and other countries. A vast amount of data supports this view. But blaming salt for high blood pressure, or hypertension, in the general population has been controversial, even described by some as a myth.
